avalancheActivity.highlights: Backcountry touring and other off-piste activities call for extensive experience in the assessment of avalanche danger and restraint. Increase in danger of dry and moist avalanches as a consequence of warming during the day and solar radiation.
avalancheActivity.comment:
As a consequence of new snow and a sometimes moderate wind from southeasterly directions, soft wind slabs formed on Sunday in particular above approximately 2500 m. The new snow and wind slabs are lying on the unfavourable surface of an old snowpack in particular on shady slopes. They remain for the foreseeable future prone to triggering. In particular above approximately 2300 m the avalanche prone locations are more prevalent. The wind slabs are covered with new snow and therefore barely recognisable.
The avalanches can be released by a single winter sport participant, in particular at transitions from a shallow to a deep snowpack, when entering gullies and bowls for example.
Whumpfing sounds and field observations confirm an unfavourable avalanche situation on steep slopes.
In particular at the base of rock walls and behind abrupt changes in the terrain medium-sized and, in isolated cases, large dry and moist avalanches are possible. As a consequence of solar radiation, the avalanche activity will gradually increase.

snowpackStructure.comment:
30 to 60 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, fell in the last seven days above approximately 2300 m. In particular along the border with France, along the border between Valais and Italy 25 to 40 cm of snow fell on Sunday above approximately 2700 m.
The high humditiy gave rise to moistening of the snowpack in all aspects below approximately 2500 m.
Monday: A clear night will be followed in the early morning by sometimes favourable conditions generally, but the avalanche danger will increase later. The surface of the snowpack will freeze, but a strong crust will not form will soften during the day.
The new snow and wind slabs are lying on a crust on steep sunny slopes.
In shady places that are protected from the wind above approximately 2300 m: The new snow is lying on the unfavourable surface of an old snowpack.
In particular at intermediate altitudes less snow than usual is lying. On sunny slopes below approximately 2200 m hardly any snow is lying.

avalancheActivity.highlights: Backcountry touring and other off-piste activities call for extensive experience in the assessment of avalanche danger and restraint. Increase in danger of dry and moist avalanches as a consequence of warming during the day and solar radiation.
avalancheActivity.comment:
As a consequence of new snow and a sometimes moderate southeasterly wind, soft wind slabs formed on Sunday.
The new snow and wind slabs of last week are lying on the unfavourable surface of an old snowpack on very steep shady slopes. In particular above approximately 2400 m these avalanche prone locations are more prevalent.
They can be released by a single winter sport participant. This applies especially at transitions from a shallow to a deep snowpack, when entering gullies and bowls for example. As a consequence of the solar radiation, the likelihood of avalanches being released will increase on steep slopes. The wind slabs are covered with new snow and therefore barely recognisable.
Whumpfing sounds and the formation of shooting cracks when stepping on the snowpack and released avalanches confirm an unfavourable avalanche situation on steep slopes.
In particular at the base of rock walls and behind abrupt changes in the terrain medium-sized and, in isolated cases, large dry and moist avalanches are possible. As a consequence of solar radiation, the avalanche activity will gradually increase.

snowpackStructure.comment:
40 to 60 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, fell in the last seven days above approximately 2300 m. 15 to 30 cm of snow fell on Sunday above approximately 2500 m.
The high humditiy gave rise to moistening of the snowpack in all aspects below approximately 2500 m.
Monday: A clear night will be followed in the early morning by sometimes favourable conditions generally, but the avalanche danger will increase later. The surface of the snowpack will freeze, but a strong crust will not form will soften during the day.
The new snow and wind slabs are lying on a crust on steep sunny slopes.
In shady places that are protected from the wind above approximately 2300 m: The new snow is lying on the unfavourable surface of an old snowpack.
In particular at intermediate altitudes less snow than usual is lying. On sunny slopes below approximately 2400 m hardly any snow is lying.

tendency.highlights: From the afternoon the weather will be cold. Evening: In some localities light snowfall. The avalanche danger will persist.

regions.name: B - VALLI DI GRESSONEY, AYAS, CHAMPORCHER

avalancheActivity.highlights: Fresh wind slabs represent the main danger. Increase in danger of dry and moist avalanches as a consequence of warming during the day and solar radiation.
avalancheActivity.comment:
As a consequence of new snow and a sometimes moderate southeasterly wind, mostly shallow wind slabs formed by Sunday. The avalanche prone locations are covered with new snow and are therefore difficult to recognise. The new snow and wind slabs of last week are lying on the unfavourable surface of an old snowpack on shady slopes.
The fresh snow and the wind slabs can be released by a single winter sport participant in some cases. This applies especially at transitions from a shallow to a deep snowpack, when entering gullies and bowls for example on very steep slopes.
Whumpfing sounds and the formation of shooting cracks when stepping on the snowpack indicate a precarious avalanche situation.
In particular above approximately 2400 m these avalanche prone locations are more prevalent.

In particular at the base of rock walls and behind abrupt changes in the terrain small and medium-sized dry and moist avalanches are possible. As a consequence of solar radiation, the avalanche activity will gradually increase.

snowpackStructure.comment:
20 to 30 cm of snow fell in the last seven days above approximately 2300 m. The wind was moderate to strong in some localities.
5 to 10 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, fell on Sunday above approximately 2000 m.
The high humditiy gave rise to moistening of the snowpack in all aspects below approximately 2400 m.
The new snow and wind slabs are lying on a crust on steep sunny slopes. The surface of the snowpack will freeze, but a strong crust will not form will soften during the day.
In shady places that are protected from the wind above approximately 2300 m: The new snow is lying on the unfavourable surface of an old snowpack.
In all aspects less snow than usual is lying. Adjacent to ridgelines and in pass areas and at high altitude a little snow is lying. At low altitude less snow than usual is lying.
